thread.title: Despite loss, Gators can build on their effort at LSU
thread.title_full: Despite loss, Gators can build on their effort at LSU

author: Edgar Thompson
title: Despite loss, Gators can build on their effort at LSU
text:
Despite loss, Gators can build on their effort at LSU 
By Edgar Thompson Mon, Oct 19, 2015 @ 12:38 am 
Three things we learned from Florida’s 35-28 loss at LSU on Saturday night: THE GATORS DON’T QUIT 
Florida fought back from two 14-point deficits and eventually tied LSU 28-28 to turn a one-sided game into a near upset. 
Tigers coach Les Miles came up with the call of the night — a fake field goal for a game-winning 16-yard touchdown. But the fact that Florida nearly went into Death Valley and beat Miles’ team showed the Gators’ confidence and resilience during Year One under coach Jim McElwain. 
Florida entered Saturday night with backup quarterback Treon Harris, failed to generate a running game (55 yards on 31 carries) and saw its vaunted secondary torched throughout the first half by much-maligned LSU sophomore Brandon Harris. 
On top of it, LSU had the nation’s top player, tailback Leonard Fournette, on its side and a capacity crowd of 102,321 cheering the Tigers. 
Yet, the Gators kept battling and erased leads of 21-7 and 28-14 to put a scare into the Tigers. 
McElwain called it a “badge of honor” that Miles’ team needed a fake field goal to beat Florida. 
McElwain did not claim a moral victory for the Gators, but he did see the kind of fight his players can build on. 
“We played hard against a really good football team,” McElwain said. “There could have been a lot of reasons for everybody, oh, these guys will fall apart. But no, we didn’t. And I didn’t expect we would.” UF STRUGGLES AGAINST GOOD RUNNING TEAMS 
The two best running teams Florida has faced — Tennessee and LSU — had their way with the Gators. 
Fournette finished with 180 yards and two touchdowns on a season-high 31 carries as the Tigers ran for 221 yards. He had to work for many of his yards. His 5.8 average per attempt was nearly three yards below his season average (8.6) entering the game. 
But the Gators could not contain the 6-foot-1, 230-pound Fournette at critical times, including the game-winning drive, when he ran for 45 yards on six carries. 
Tennessee’s rushing attack piled up 254 yards. 
With Nick Chubb out for Georgia, the Gators will not have to face one of the nation’s top tailbacks. Backup Sony Michel is good, but he managed just 87 yards on 26 carries during the Bulldogs’ 9-6 snoozer against Missouri. 
Florida State’s Dalvin Cook still awaits in the regular-season finale. The 6-foot, 203-pound Cook lacks the size of Fournette but is as explosive as any back in the nation. 
The Gators need to find answers by then. CALLAWAY IS UF’S BEST PLAYMAKER IN YEARS 
The search for a playmaker on the perimeter is over. Antonio Callaway single-handedly — and one-handedly — kept the Gators within striking distance of the Tigers. 
Callaway’s one-handed, 48-yard catch set up a 19-yard touchdown by tight end Jake McGee to cut LSU’s lead to 21-14. With Florida trailing 28-21, Callaway returned a punt 72 yards for a touchdown. 
Callaway — the hero against Tennessee — had the ball in his hands in the end zone with a chance to tie the game. But LSU defensive back Dwayne Thomas ripped the ball away. 
Callaway came up with a 41-yard catch on the final drive, but the Gators stalled, no fault of Callaway, who finished with 100 receiving yards on three catches.
